courseTitle: Survey of Plant and Animal Cells Virtual Lab

pageData.titleName2: Survey of Plant and Animal Cells Virtual Lab

pageData.text: This investigation introduces the basic organization of two types of eukaryotic cells. Through the process of mounting, staining, and examining cells, you will compare the structural components of animal and plant cells. In addition, you will analyze plant and animal cell micrographs, or photos or magnified slides.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos

text: Create, view, and interpret slides from samples of human epithelial tissue and onion epidermal tissue.
Describe the basic structural components of eukaryotic cells and their functions.
Explain similarities and differences between animal and plant cell structures.

pageData.text: Plants may not have feet, but they can still move. Plants respond to sunlight and stretch toward it. But not only can plants stretch and grow in the location where they are rooted, but they can also migrate slowly over time in response to other environmental conditions. It is predicted that as climate change continues to warm the planet, plants and animals will move northward into cooler, but warming, regions. However, scientists have discovered that some plants are moving south to warmer climates.In 2014, researchers compiled data for over 300 plant species over a diverse geographic range in North America and looked at plant movement over the last 40 years. They discovered that over 60% of the species were moving south into warmer regions, not north as had been predicted1. The plants migrated because along with increasing temperatures, these regions also experienced increased amounts of rainfall. How the plants will continue to cope with warmer temperatures is unknown, but certainly in order to survive in warmer climates plants need water. If the precipitation patterns continue to change, the plants may have to uproot and move again.
Reference1Balmer, J. (2014, August 8). Plants have unexpected response to climate change. Science.https://www.science.org/content/article/plants-have-unexpected-response-climate-change#

pageData.desc: A alpine mountain meadow with a little snow on the grass.
pageData.altText: A alpine mountain meadow with a little snow on the grass.

pageData.text: Cells are the basic structural units of living things. They are categorized into two groups, prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. All of the specimens in this activity are eukaryotic, which means that each cell possesses a and membrane-bound residing in the cytoplasm.Cytoplasm is the gel-like, space filling medium inside cells. Organelles reside in the cytoplasm and are small parts of the cell with specialized functions. Typically, the largest of these is the nucleus. The nucleus is the control center of cellular operations. The nucleus contains , which is the inherited material that determines the traits of an organism.Eukaryotic organisms can be multicellular (made of more than one cell), such as plants, animals and most fungi, or unicellular (made of only one cell), such as some algae, protozoans, and yeast.

pageData.subTitle: Comparison of Plant and Animal Cells
pageData.text: In contrast to plant cells (Figure 1), animal cells (Figure 2) do not have a <button class='glossary-text'>cell wall</button>. They also differ from plant cells in that they possess many small <button class='glossary-text'>vacuoles</button> (a membrane-bound area that stores nutients or waste) instead of one large, space-filling vacuole. Because of these two characteristics, animal cells are more flexible and pliable than plant cells. This is important for animals, because they must be flexible for locomotion. For example, as an earthworm moves through the dirt; it can curl, twist, bend, and stretch, depending on where it wants to go. These actions would be difficult to perform if the cells were stiff with rigid cell walls. The structural design of plant cells and animal cells contributes to the functions of the organism as a whole.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Generalized plant cell with organelles labeled.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Generalized plant cell with organelles labeled.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Generalized animal cell with organelles labeled.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Generalized animal cell with organelles labeled.

pageData.text:
0312 Animal Cell and Components.jpg by OpenStax is available under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license at
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:0312_Animal_Cell_and_Components.jpg
Both plant cells and animal cells require nutrients and other raw materials to perform life functions.
They also need <button class='glossary-text'>mitochondria</button> (singular, mitochondrion) to convert sugar into energy. Mitochondria are typically kidney-shaped.

The <button class='glossary-text'>lysosome</button> is another <button class='glossary-text'>organelle</button> common to both animal and plant cells. Lysosomes are round vesicles that contain enzymes that break down and recycle molecules in the cell.

<button class='glossary-text'>Chloroplasts</button> are organelles only found in plant cells that enable them to perform photosynthesis to convert energy from the sun into food. Chloroplasts contain a green pigment called <button class='glossary-text'>chlorophyll</button>, which is responsible for the green color of plants. Animal cells do not have chloroplasts.

All plant and animal cells are surrounded by a , but plant cells are also encased by a . The cell wall is a rigid outer covering made of cellulose that gives plant cells a definite shape. This is important for the support structure of plants. It allows for the buildup of high pressures, which is known as turgor, giving plants stability even during harsh environmental conditions. Plants do not have bones or a skeleton; therefore, they rely on sturdy cell walls for support. The large of a plant cell also contributes to the cell shape by acting as a space-filling structure that maintains pressure inside the cell membrane and cell wall. When a plant becomes dehydrated, the vacuole empties and the plant wilts.

In contrast, an extracellular matrix made of fibrous proteins and other materials allows animal cells to be anchored into tissues, providing support and the maintenance of body shape to even small, simple animals. Cartilage and bone help maintain structure and shape in larger animals.

tableData.text: Separates the intracellular components from the extracellular space and allows transport in and out of cell
Provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment
Translate messenger RNAs into proteins; ribosomes can be free in the cytoplasm or bound to the endoplasmic reticulum
Packages and processes proteins and lipids for transport to designated locations in the cell

Smooth ER stores lipids, assists in movement of newly synthesized proteins, and houses important enzymes; some ribosomes are attached to the rough ER, which participates in folding and sorting of newly synthesized proteins
Produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP
Carry out photosynthesis to produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP
Microtubular structures that participate in chromosome separation during cell division
Provide storage space for food or water
Digest foreign materials and unwanted organelles in the cytoplasm
*There is some evidence to suggest that some plants have structures with a similar function, but there is disagreement about whether to call them lysosomes or vacuoles.
tableData.hoverText: *There is some evidence to suggest that some plants have structures with a similar function, but there is disagreement about whether to call them lysosomes or vacuoles.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes what happens to plant cells when a plant becomes dehydrated?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When a plant becomes dehydrated, the vacuole empties, causing turgor to decrease and the plant to wilt.

pageData.question: Which of the following molecules gives plant cell walls rigidity?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The cell wall is a rigid outer covering made of cellulose.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: All plant and animal cells are surrounded by a cell membrane, but plant cells are also encased by a cell wall. The cell wall is a rigid outer covering made of cellulose that gives plant cells a definite shape. This is important for the support structure of plants. It allows for the buildup of high pressures, which is known as turgor, giving plants stability even during harsh environmental conditions. Plants do not have bones or a skeleton; therefore, they rely on sturdy cell walls for support. The large vacuole of a plant cell also contributes to the cell shape by acting as a space-filling structure that maintains pressure inside the cell membrane and cell wall. When a plant becomes dehydrated, the vacuole empties and the plant wilts.

pageData.question: In this investigation, what type of cells will you be viewing?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: All the specimens in this activity are eukaryotic.

pageData.question: Which of the following characteristics is unique to eukaryotes?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Eukaryotes, unlike prokaryotes, are a group of living things with cells containing membrane-bound organelles (such as a nucleus) and can be either multicellular or unicellular.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Cells are the basic structural units of living things. They are categorized into two groups, prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Eukaryotic cells possess a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles residing in the cytoplasm.Cytoplasm is the gel-like, space filling medium inside cells. Organelles reside in the cytoplasm and are small parts of the cell with specialized functions.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is only present in plant cells?
Animal cells lack the rigidity of plant cells. Which of the following best describes how animals maintain their structure and shape?

options.text: Animal cells are anchored within tissues by an extracellular matrix.
Animal cells are surrounded by a protein capsule that can be flexible or rigid.
Animal cells are pressurized by large fluid-filled vacuoles.
Animal cells have mineralized cell membranes.
Animal cells adhere to one another by their lysosomes.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is usually only present in animal cells?
What is the membrane-bound area in a plant cell that stores nutrients or waste?
Which of the following organelles is only found in plant cells?
This organelle is found only in animal cells and is a microtubular structure that participates in chromosome separation during cell division.

Obtain all needed materials. You may want to use this drawing template to organize your drawings.

In Activity 1, you will use a virtual simulation to prepare an unstained slide of onion epidermal cells. You will then prepare a stained version of the same cells. You will observe these slides in Activity 3.
In Activity 2, you will use a virtual simulation to prepare a stained human cheek epithelial cell slide. You will observe this slide in Activity 3.
In Activity 3, you will complete a tutorial of the virtual microscope before using it to observe the slides prepared in Activities 1 and 2.
Complete the virtual microscope tutorial before starting Activity 3.
In Activity 4, you will compare your drawings to micrographs of similar plant and animal tissues.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

tableData.text: Separates the intracellular components from the extracellular space and allows transport in and out of cell
Provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment
Translate messenger RNAs into proteins; ribosomes can be free in the cytoplasm or bound to the endoplasmic reticulum
Packages and processes proteins and lipids for transport to designated locations in the cell

Smooth ER stores lipids, assists in movement of newly synthesized proteins, and houses important enzymes; some ribosomes are attached to the rough ER, which participates in folding and sorting of newly synthesized proteins
Produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP
Carry out photosynthesis to produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP
Microtubular structures that participate in chromosome separation during cell division
Provide storage space for food or water
Digest foreign materials and unwanted organelles in the cytoplasm
*There is some evidence to suggest that some plants have structures with a similar function, but there is disagreement about whether to call them lysosomes or vacuoles.
tableData.hoverText: *There is some evidence to suggest that some plants have structures with a similar function, but there is disagreement about whether to call them lysosomes or vacuoles.

data.title: Cell membrane
data.content: Separates the intracellular components from the extracellular space and allows transport in and out of cell

data.title: Cell wall
data.content: Provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment

data.title: Centrioles
data.content: Tubular structures located on opposite sides of the cell that function in the formation of the spindle fibers during cell division; found only in animal cells

data.title: Chlorophyll
data.content: A green pigment present in all green plants and in cyanobacteria th at absorbs light to provide energy for photosynthesis

data.title: Chloroplast
data.content: Carries out photosynthesis to produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP

data.title: DNA
data.content: The inherited material stored in the nucleus of eukarotyic cells; stands for deoxyribonucleic acid

data.title: Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
data.content: One of two different types of ER; smooth ER stores lipids, assists in movement of newly synthesized proteins, and houses important enzymes; rough ER participates in folding and sorting of newly synthesized proteins and may have attached ribosomes

data.title: Golgi apparatus
data.content: Packages and processes proteins and lipids for transport to designated locations in the cell

data.title: Lysosome
data.content: Membrane-bound organelle that contains digestive enzymes, removal of worn out cellular material and pathogens

data.title: Mitochondria
data.content: Produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP; singular, mitochondrion

data.title: Organelle
data.content: A specialized structure that performs a specific function inside the cell; the term means "little organ"

data.title: Ribosome
data.content: A complex molecular machine that produces proteins

data.title: Vacuole
data.content: A membrane-bound area that stores nutients or waste
